Data centers are promising participants in demand reponse
Large yet flexible energy demands!
Multi-tenant colocation data center
Multiple tenants house their own servers in one shared space and manage their equipment independently
Data center operator is only responsible for facility management (e.g., power distribution, cooling)
Why colocation demand response?
In reality
Most large data centers are built to host servers from multiple companies (often called colocation data centers, or "colos").
--- The Datacenter as a Computer, a study by Google Research in 2013
Colocation is growing
Therere over 1,000 colocation data centers in the U.S.
Projected to grow to US$ 43 billion by 2018
Annual compound growth rate of 11%

Split incentive
Colocation operator desires demand response but has no control over tenants servers
Tenants manage servers but have no incentive for demand response
We need to incentivize tenants for colocation demand response
iCODE
Incentive mechanism based on negotiation
Step 1: Each participating tenant decides its bid, including planned energy reduction and desired payment
Step 2: Colocation operator chooses winning bids
Model
Tenant
: energy reduction (by turning off unused servers)
: requested payment is a non-decreasing function of energy reduction
Switching cost + delay cost
Colocation operator
: incentive rate provided by load serving entity for each unit energy reduction
Decide winning bids to maximize energy reduction subject to no profit loss constraint
LSE benefits from peak energy reduction
Colocation operator reduces energy at no additional cost
Tenants receives financial compensation without affecting application performance
maximize bids
